data.text: Aerodynamics of Bikepacking Rigs

Seeing as this group pays attention to weight, maybe itÂ´s a good place to discuss aerodynamics as well? IÂ´m turning a 29 hardtail mtb into an aero bikepacking race machine :) Aero is much more important than most people give it credit for, also in bikepacking, even if you never ride very fast. Think about all the headwinds, for one. Also, anytime you ride faster than 12km/h aero has a bigger impact than rolling resistance. IÂ´m by no means an expert but IÂ´d like to share a bit about what IÂ´ve learned recently, and maybe we can come up with good ideas and solutions together? First IÂ´d like to invite more people to consider aero bars. They really help you stay in a relaxed, supported aero shape and can save HUGE amounts of watts. People think theyÂ´re heavy but people also use heavy front harnesses and strap wide front rolls to them that cause insane amounts of drag. In a wind tunnel they tested a tiny 2.5l front bag and at only 25km/h it added 8.5W of drag, which is huge, and at faster speeds that number rises exponentially! Imagine how much drag the huge rolls/bags people use cause then. If you mount aero bars, you can easily attach a dry bag inline instead and donÂ´t need the extra weight of a harness. If you use a tapered dry bag, instead of it slowing you down immensely, it may actually make you faster! Cyclite has a 5l semi rigid aero front bag that has been tested to make you faster. I have an Alpkit 13l tapered dry bag that IÂ´m going to try to use to get the same effect. IÂ´m also considering ordering another one to put on the bag stabilizer in the back. There IÂ´d have the tapered end facing back, and this should help clean up the airflow and make me faster as well. Going to put an old top tube bag underneath my Ortlieb fram bag and fill that space better. Then strap something to the downtube and fill up the remaining room in the triangle, Theoretically then, IÂ´d have the front tapered dry bag gently cut the wind, sending it around the bike. Then the filled triangle keeps the wind flowing reasonably smoothly to the back where the rear tapered dry bag smooths it out more and gently releases it. My moving legs get in the way of course but I canÂ´t do much about that :) I hope and believe that this system will make me more aero than having no bags at all on the bike, something which cannot be said for most setups. Putting 32mm Schwalbe Pro One road racing tyres with latex tubes on the bike so I can be faster on the road and light gravel. Planning to carry my XC tires as well and eventually do 200km road rides to the mountains and then do trail riding with the XC tyres there. Thoughts, ideas? I have more to write but donÂ´t want to make the post too long :)
Just keep pedaling.âœŒï¸

data.text: Not sure I'm gonna do any actual races, but I'm gonna ride in that fashion often with loooong days in the saddle. Many people seem to think that aero = uncomfort, but that's just preconditioned thinking. You don't need a super aggressive time trial position. A relaxed aero bar position is super comfortable. It's a resting position for me. And aero is much more than just body position, even though that's the biggest factor When more people realise just how much drag handlebar bags and rolls create, we're gonna see a change in how we carry bags. Even if you just used aero bars as an attachment point for mounting a dry bag inline and nothing else, that would still make you more efficient, especially if using a tapered dry bag. When you add the resting position and huge watt savings of being in aero bars, it becomes a no brainer. And aero bars' weight is pretty close to the weight of many handlebar harnesses people use. I focused on the aero discussion in my post, but the main point of focus for this bike is long distance COMFORT. I've got a Kinekt suspension seatpost that allows me to stay seated over bumps and saves both my ass and legs. A supremely comfortable noseless ISM saddle, front suspension, and that resting position in the aero bars.

data.text: it is good that you are thinking and reading about aerodynamics and weight. Couple of things: - regardless of shaving weight or making your bike Aero, those suspensions on your MT will waste a lot of your energy while paddling. - unlike the general assumption, Aero bars do not always add comfort. They add extra hand position (useful for super long rides) and aerodynamics, but that doesn't always mean comfort. The main two problem with Aerobar are 1) reducing access to the horizontal portion of handle bar. Mine is Flip Ergo 50a which at least doesn't have this problem, but still 2) Aero bars generally need a different saddle position compared to normal (and drop bar) riding. The saddle needs to be a bit move forward and tiny bit head down. In general a normal bike fit and saddle position is not very comfortable for Aero bar and vice versa a bike fit and saddle position for Aero bar is not comfortable (and fit!) for normal position. - the general thing you mentioned about aerodynamics is correct and there are plenty thing online (from cyclingabout and other resources) on this. But 1) anytime you move weight away from rear tire to the front of the bike, you are reducing traction on the rear wheel which is the main place for forward move force 2) comfort of access also affect the overall time. If bike packing setup need 3% less Watts than rear panniers, but with rear Pannier you can access things more quickly or have fewer stops because you can carry slightly more nutilrition, than it will depend on the route and your speed characteristics which one will take less time overall. 3) as you reduce your overall gear capacity, then you have to carry less and less and (more importantly) smaller and smaller stuff. That can quickly skyrocket the cost of your gears. e.g. instead of sleeping bag you already have, need to get a lighter smaller one, same for cooking, same for tent, etc. All above said, I agree with you that between aerodynamics and weight, in majority of cases aerodynamics is more important and shaving of 1kg of gear does not have as big an effect as people think. But at the end comfort is the most important factor to me in long rides: comfort > aerodynamics > weight.

data.text: There's a lot to address here and not that much time to do it, but I'll start now and finish later today. Sure, the susp fork wastes some energy but mostly I have it locked out so not a big deal. It's mostly gonna be used for steeper trail stuff. Limited access to horizontal area of handlebar I agree is a con. It makes it harder to fit stem bags and such, but not impossible. In my opinion normal bike saddles are dangerous, so that's why I use an ISM saddle, which also takes care of the issue with saddle position with the aero bars as I can easily scoot forward on it and be very comfortable or sit further back and be equally comfortable in a more upright mtb position. Most importantly, no restricted blood flow and numbing, so no danger to my reproductive organs. Bikepacking bags don in general force you to take less and lighter stuff yes, but that's a good thing, as it means your bike will handle better and your riding will be more enjoyable. Remember that we're in an UL bikepacking group now, so I spoke to an audience that already thinks about that balance. For this bike, I need to both be aero and fast for long road stretches as well as having the weight weil balanced so I can do more technical mountain biking. The front and rear bags are just for very light sleep/camp stuff, so all the weight is as centered as possible and everything I need to access during the day is also in the center of the bike I agree comfort is most important. It doesn't have to be at the expense of aero though. The main goal of this build is comfort and so far it seens to be working well. To me though, there's a difference between comfort and lazyness. The fact that you have to plan the setup and use it in specific ways isn't uncomfortable. It's just being deliberate in how you do things, in order to reap the rewards.
